snippet: After years of treatment and two relapses of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Dr. Lukas Wartman had exhausted all conventional approaches to his disease. A group at Washington University in St. Louis spent a month decoding his genetic information, a...
lead_paragraph: After years of treatment and two relapses of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, Dr. Lukas Wartman had exhausted all conventional approaches to his disease. A group at Washington University in St. Louis spent a month decoding his genetic information, a process called whole genome sequencing, in hopes of determining the genetic cause of his leukemia. The team found an overactive gene that was treatable with a drug for advanced kidney cancer. Here is how the process works.

headline.seo: Searching for a Cancer’s Vulnerable Target
headline.main: Searching for a Cancer’s Vulnerable Target
